monogr.title: Studies in the Determination and Evaluation of the Dominical Logoi as Cited in the Original Text of the Greek Didascalia Apostolorum

biblStruct.note: For the "determination" of the dominical logoi as cited in the original text of the Greek Didascalia, these "studies" propose and apply new and more adequate methodologies than have been employed heretofore; and for the "evaluation" of said logoi they apply the formgeschichtlich and redaktionsgeschichtlich methodologies -methodologies that have not been employed (in the study of the Didascalist's citations) heretofore. As a result of the application of these methodologies, it has been demonstrated that the Didascalist's immediate source - the "Gospel," as the Didascalist himself refers to it again and again - is not to be defined as any individual Gospel (e g. the Gospel of Matthew), or any collection of Gospels (e g. the Synoptics), nor is it to be defined as a "harmony" of the Gospels. Kather it is to be defined as the entire body of "Gospel" traditions available to the Didascalist - a body of traditions that consisted, as far as the evidence in the Didascalia itself will allow definition, in the main, of a collection or, more probably, collections of logoi Jesu - collections which, like the collections of logoi Jesu, Q, and the Gospel of Thomas, contained comparatively little, if any gospel narrative material. All of the dominical logoi analyzed in these "studies" probably derive inmmediately from such collections of logoi Jesu, e.g., the logoi cited at Didasc. I.1.7 and III.11.3 (Study, II), Didasc. II.16.1 and VI.14.4 (Study, IV), Didasc. II.36.9 (Study, VI), and Didasc. VI.13.3 and VI.14.8 (Study, VII) undoubtedly derive immediately from such collections; the logos cited at Didasc. I.1.4 (Stzldy, I ) probably derives immediately from such collections; and the logoi cited at Didasc. I.6.10, II.34.7, VI.12.11, and VI.17.6 (Study, III), and Didasc. II.20.1 and II.32.2 (Study, V) likely derive irrznzediately from such collections. Those collections consisted of logoi Jesu that were derived ultimately from a variety of sources: (i) the canonical Gospels, e.g.. the logoi cited at Didasc. I.6.10, II.34.7, VI.12.11, and VI.17.6 (Study, III) and Didasc. VI.13.3 and VI.14.8 (Study, VII) clearly derive ultimately from the Gospel of Matthew, and the logoi cited at Didasc. II.20.1 and II.32.2 (Study, V) clearly derives ultimately from the Gospel of Luke: and (ii) non-canonical sources, e.g., the logoi cited at Didasc. I.1.7 and III.11.3 (Study, II), Didasc. II.16.1 and VI.14.4 (Study, IV), and Didasc. II.36.9 (Study, VI) clearly derive ultirrzately from a source, or sources, quite independent of the Synoptic Gospels, though, in the case of the logoi cited at Didasc. I.1.7 and III.11.3 (Study, II) and Didasc. II.16.1 and VI.14.4 (Study, IV), parallel to them.
